text: ‚ÄúRace has steered our immigration policy going way back,‚Äù and a majority of the court is ‚Äújust not ready to deal with that,‚Äù said Richard Boswell, a law professor at UC Hastings in San Francisco. https://t.co/FTNAnK3v5s

name: sfchronicle
text:

https://t.co/Yx5BZGxb4e

name: sfchronicle
text:
Lisa Alexander, who stirred outrage after confronting a man stenciling ‚ÄúBlack Lives Matter‚Äù outside his own S.F. home, complains to city officials, saying she did not make the 911 call that drew police to check on the alleged vandalism 

https://t.co/4oOwvmQHIu

name: sfchronicle
text: The recent surge of coronavirus infections in California is driving up demand for testing and triggering a resurgence in delays, forcing many people to wait up to a week. Have you been tested recently? https://t.co/cUQcwzOrRe

text: The policy, dubbed BerkDOT, aims to decriminalize minor traffic violations that disproportionately impact Black and brown people by creating a new Berkeley Department of Transportation. https://t.co/FKfO0jSapP

text: The "Hamilton" discourse begins anew in 2020, a time of racial and historical reckoning: https://t.co/tY1PdLuNzf

name: sfchronicle
text:
Pac-12 announces football and other fall sports will play a conference-only schedule due to concerns over the coronavirus pandemic. 

https://t.co/KDj5NqaLWX

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: 66 people infected with the coronavirus and at least one resident dead in outbreak at Marin Post Acute skilled nursing facility in San Rafael. https://t.co/YX5qGGERs5

name: sfchronicle
text:
Eduardo Martinez, the man killed by Contra Costa deputies after allegedly opening fire, had held his ex-girlfriend hostage overnight, authorities said.

Deputies say he told his former girlfriend that he would shoot and did not want to return to jail.

https://t.co/KGIpRGHbQc

name: sfchronicle
text:
Update: Five residents dead and 66 infected in coronavirus outbreak at a Marin County skilled nursing facility.

The 66 reported cases are comprised of 49 residents and 17 staff members.

https://t.co/nHQQSj2vC1

name: sfchronicle
text: JUST IN: COVID-19 hospitalizations in California grew to an all-time high Friday as state health officials reported 6,171 total patients. https://t.co/WZJqK1LM1s

name: sfchronicle
text:
The coronavirus surge in California is driving up demand for testing, but many are encountering long waits to get a test or see results. 

What's behind these delays? https://t.co/fjqd4Kt5Ys

name: sfchronicle
text: Bay Area quesabirria pop-up sensation El Garage opens brick-and-mortar restaurant. The Richmond's restaurant's meteoric rise speaks to the irresistible nature of its crispy quesabirria tacos, full of tender braised beef and gooey cheese. https://t.co/sFltplIFUH https://t.co/fLGscY0RPM

name: sfchronicle
text:
Oakland officials push ‚ÄúGive the Lake a Break‚Äù campaign urging people to avoid crowding at Lake Merritt to reduce coronavirus transmission.

Officials will close roads and restrict parking around the lake from 7:30 a.m. to 11 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. https://t.co/kUzP3e07nC

name: sfchronicle
text: Do you miss fair food, horse racing and contests? State and county fairs are mostly cancelled, but here are some ways you can still participate in the fun and stay safe in the Bay Area: https://t.co/z8vGws81dz

name: sfchronicle
text: The menu at Absinthe team‚Äôs new S.F. restaurant  - Arbor - has a focus on salads and sandwiches and plant-based options. Arbor takes over the former Arlequin Cafe space.  https://t.co/xfX5F3AwEM https://t.co/sb12a4fq7O

name: sfchronicle
text: Cinegogue Summer Days kicks off July 16, with a special Drive-in screening under the stars at the Westwind Drive-Ins in Concord and San Jose, followed by virtual film screenings, interactive conversations, premiere performances, and award presentations. https://t.co/hnvWhPflt0

name: sfchronicle
text: Under stricter health rules, outdoor dining is now prohibited in Alameda County, officials said Friday. The county‚Äôs health order already approved outdoor dining, but restaurants, wineries and bars can now only offer drive-through or pick-up service. https://t.co/WlCRioX9Yg

name: sfchronicle
text:
A Black Lives Matter mural in Martinez vandalized. A white couple in St. Louis points guns at protesters. 

Backlash to the BLM movement was swift. Columnist @OtisRTaylorJr talks to historians about why it was expected: https://t.co/O5Lnf56PJz

name: sfchronicle
text: A multi-car crash on the Bay Bridge east of Treasure Island tied up traffic for about an hour Friday night. https://t.co/1ELVH2V74s

name: sfchronicle
text:
A three-alarm fire burned three multi-story buildings in Pacific Heights, with flames and thick smoke pouring from the rooftops. Firefighters had the blaze under control by 9 p.m.

text:

https://t.co/keIJM0fyWo

name: sfchronicle
text: Experts had been afraid that homeless people could get the coronavirus in huge numbers, but thanks to leased hotel rooms, thinning out shelters and other measures, their fears have so far not been borne out. https://t.co/VR32xLICHg

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @hknightsf: My latest: San Francisco‚Äôs 55,000 public school kids will learn mostly from home on the computer this year. Distance learning didn‚Äôt go well in the spring, but the district has given teachers no additional guidance on how to make it successful since March. https://t.co/KgCQNgzehp

name: sfchronicle
text: San Francisco requires daily hotel room cleanings and disinfection unless a guest declines. Hotel owners say the cost is prohibitive for a struggling industry. https://t.co/nKm3WHDqCd

name: sfchronicle
text:
Bay Area property tax rolls are up 6.7% this year, but the coronavirus could dampen growth next year if home sales and demand for office space continue to fall.

@kathpender has more: https://t.co/MUuKZeZ2H7

name: sfchronicle
text: Cities and counties depend on property taxes to fund services. The coronavirus could dampen growth next year if home sales and demand for office space continue to fall, reports @kathpender. https://t.co/enfCDWlSOm

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @rachelswan: SF transportation chief @JeffreyTumlin envisioned a city in which cars are no longer king. Now he‚Äôs facing the biggest crisis in Muni‚Äôs history ‚Äî and a critical test of leadership. https://t.co/o529HJ0OIS

name: sfchronicle
text:
When Jeffrey Tumlin stepped in as transportation chief of San Francisco, activists prayed he‚Äôd be a savior.

Barely seven months into the job, his department faces losses of up to $568 million over four years, battered by an economic shutdown and pandemic. https://t.co/UVo4ZPPur9

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @SportingGreenSF: On this date in 1961, the NL All-stars rallied in the 10th inning for a 5-4 victory over the AL at Candlestick Park after Stu Miller's long-debated balk with one out in the ninth. 

Roberto Clemente singled home Willie Mays with the winning run. https://t.co/vhsgK4SHRJ

name: sfchronicle
text: Buster Posey is well respected as a baseball player. It‚Äôs not just the ability that made him the glue to three World Series titles but the character that earns him respect among teammates, opponents and fans, writes @JohnSheaHey. https://t.co/uKKUGg8XmZ

name: sfchronicle
text: Joseph Liebling, the energetic and resourceful choral conductor whose leadership helped shape the sounds of numerous Bay Area ensembles died Saturday, July 4, of heart failure. He was 93. https://t.co/r65lql5vW3

text:
